title: New York delays new cybersecurity rules for financial firms
title_page: New York delays new cybersecurity rules for financial firms - Business Insider
text:

In response to the growing threat from cyber attacks to financial institutions, New York State had planned to enforce new cybersecurity rules for banks and insurers as of January 1, but has now postponed that to March 1, according to Reuters.
The rules were originally proposed in September but the industry complained they failed to adequately distinguish between large and small firms, and that they may clash with future federal regulations. As a result, the state revised the regulation, publishing a new version on December 28. The proposed March 1 enforcement date allows for a feedback period.
The new rules are comprehensive, likely making it expensive and complex for banks and insurers to achieve compliance. Among other requirements, financial institutions will now have to provide annual reports to the state proving they are compliant, maintain comprehensive audit trails, report any cybersecurity event within 72 hours of occurrence, appoint a Chief Information Security Officer (CISO), and introduce multifactor authentication for staff accessing internal networks or information systems externally. The last provision is likely designed to help combat breaches of interbank networks such as SWIFT, which has been repeatedly attacked over the last year.
If they are implemented, it would present a significant opportunity for regtechs. Regtechs are firms that aim to help other companies more easily achieve compliance. While they may not be able to reduce the burden of appointing a CISO, many specialize in automating the production of reports for regulators, as well as automatically detecting cybersecurity events and alerting the relevant parties. This suggests that financial institutions in New York should consider working with a regtech if the new cybersecurity rules come into force to ease their path to compliance.
BI Intelligence, Business Insider's premium research service, has compiled a detailed report on cybersecurity that details the current landscape for companies in critical infrastructure sectors, as well as how companies can protect their control systems from hackers.
Here are some of the key points from the report:
Companies that operate critical infrastructure sites reported 295 cyber incidents in 2015, up from 245 in 2014.
Hackers are targeting the industrial control systems that operate critical infrastructure because of the enormous damage they can cause by crippling such infrastructure.
Industrial control systems typically weren't designed to be connected to the internet, so they weren't built with cybersecurity capabilities to ward off hackers.
The hack that caused a blackout in the Ukraine could serve as a blueprint for other hackers that want to target critical infrastructure, helping them succeed in future attackers.
The Ukraine hack highlighted the importance of training employees about cybersecurity and placing additional access controls on industrial control systems beyond firewalls.
